StrideShow is a client-mobile presentation tool

Download the mobile app

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED but optional: the app is a significant part of a stridshow presentation

The rest of this tutorial involves the mobile app

On the app, click the demo button

In the demo activity, enter this generated number into your mobile device and wait for the mobile panel on the right to indicate that your mobile device has connected

On your mobile device, you should now see the presentations. This presentation titled 'Instructions' should be highlighted green. Tap the presentation to control it through your phone. The mobile panel will tell you when you are connected

You can now swipe left and right on the app to traverse the slideshow. Continue viewing this on mobile

Switch to full screen

Try the laser pointer

Try the magnifying glass

That's it for this tutorial. Exit the slideshow and check out the other presentations in this demo

Aren’t you just bored with all those slides-based presentations?
Don’t you think that presentations given in modern browsers shouldn’t copy the limits of ‘classic’ slide decks?
Would you like to impress your audience with stunning visualization of your talk?
then you should try

impress.js*

* no rhyme intended

It’s a presentation tool
inspired by the idea behind prezi.com
and based on the power of CSS3 transforms and transitions in modern browsers.

visualize your big thoughts

and tiny ideas

by positioning, rotating and scaling them on an infinite canvas

the only limit is your imagination

want to know more?

use the source, Luke!

one more thing...

have you noticed it’s in 3D*?

* beat that, prezi ;)

Introduction to Vault for Users

Created by Hashicorp

Hashicorp

  • Consul
  • Vagrant
  • Terraform

Securely stores and controls access to:

  • tokens
  • passwords
  • certificates
  • API keys

Features

  • Access controls
  • Audit logs
  • Encrypted storage
  • Break glass features

Interface: Command line

Secrets Backends

  • Are "roots" of a filesystem
  • Different types of backends for different types of secrets
  • Types: generic, aws, cubbyhole, and more
$ vault mounts
$ vault mounts
PATH           TYPE           DESCRIPTION

General/       generic        general secrets
awsBackend/    aws            dynamic aws secrets
Gene42dev/     generic        secrets for Gene42 devs
Gene42clients/ generic        secrets belonging to Gene42 clients
PhenotipsDev/  generic        secrets phenotips developers
sys/           system         system endpoint used for control, ...
Cubbybox/      cubbybox       per token secrets

Authentication: Tokens

  • Vault has no sense of users, only tokens
  • Everybody authenticates with tokens
  • $ vault auth d08e2bd5-ffb0-440d-6486-b8f650ec8c0c
  • Once authenticated, tokens are stored locally
  • Tokens are automatically included in commands that require permissions
  • Tokens are assigned permissions

Authentication Backends

  • Other methods to generate tokens
  • Entry points to get tokens
      • Examples
    • Github backend
    • Userpass backend
    • Token backend
    • TLS certificates
    • many others

Userpass

  • Use a username and password to generate a token
$ vault auth -methods=userpass \
     username=foo \
     password=bar
  • Permissions are set to userpass entries instead of tokens

TTL & Max TTL

  • Time to Live
  • Tokens and secrets have ttl's
  • Static secrets don't depend on ttl's. They exist until deleted
  • Dynamic secrets and tokens are deleted at the end of their ttl
  • TTL's can be renewed until Max TTL is reached
    Example for userpass
  • Userpass tokens with TTL = Max_TTL = 8 hours
  • Generated tokens last a "work day"

User permissions

  • Create
  • Read
  • Update
  • List
  • sudo
  • deny (default)
path "secret/*" {
   capabilities = ["read", "list", "create", "update"]
}

path "secret/foo" {
   capabilities = ["read"]
}

path "secret/super-secret" {
   capabilities = ["deny"]
}

Writing a secret

$ vault write secret/devPassword \
     username=admin \
     password=Admin \
     ...
1 2 3 4
  1. Vault executable
  2. Command (Write)
  3. Path (Backend: secret)
  4. Key value pairs

Reading a secret

$ vault read secret/devPassword
1 2 3
  1. Vault executable
  2. Command (Read)
  3. Path
KEY            VALUE
username       admin
password       Admin
...

Listing a secret

$ vault list secret
1 2 3
  1. Vault executable
  2. Command (List)
  3. Path
KEYS
devPassword
...

Deleting a secret

$ vault delete secret/devPassword
1 2 3
Success! Deleted 'secret/devPassword' if it existed.

Aside: GPG with Vault

  • Sending secrets outside of Vault
  • Keeping tokens and/or auth backend credentials (eg userpass)
